body: Daniel Arsham was barely aware of Merce Cunningham in 2005, when he got a call telling him that he was being considered as the set designer for the next work by Cunningham's dance company. Mr. Arsham was 25 and just two years out of art school at the Cooper Union. ''I knew him from my studies,'' he said recently, ''but as a passing name.'' A few
title: Cunningham Fostered Serendipity In Set Design

body: Aristotle believed circular motion to be a distinguishing characteristic of perfection. If you have ever seen a world-class runner cruise around a track, you may well agree that a body curving in motion is a sight of beauty. On a snowy day in late October, Luis Galvan was not particularly quick or light as he trudged around the otherwise deserted
title: Where Lives Overlap

body: On a rainy Wednesday in Brooklyn, one might have expected some enthusiasm for a new law that next year will allow livery cabs to be hailed on the street in northern Manhattan and the four other boroughs. Instead, some who work with livery cabs were skeptical about the effect the law might have, while those in the yellow cab business worried about
title: In Cab Industry, Shrugs and Concerns Over New Livery Law

body: SOME couples fight for fun. Others do it out of frustration. For Dasha Libin, a Soviet émigré, and Dan Anderson, who hails from Arkansas, fighting is a passion. title: VOWS; Dasha Libin and Dan Anderson

body: For months, they were the best of neighbors: the slapdash champions of economic equality, putting down stakes in an outdoor plaza, and the venerable Episcopal parish next door, whose munificence helped sustain the growing protest. title: Occupy Group Faults Church, A Onetime Ally

body: For more than a half-century, the filmmaker, artist, poet, critic, programmer and ecstatic theologian of cinema Jonas Mekas has been viewing the world through a camera, often in the form of visual diaries. A restless image maker, he seizes moments of beauty and life as it happens in work that bridges outer and inner, the self and the other. The
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'SLEEPLESS NIGHTS STORIES'; Preservationist's Home Movies: A Lifetime of Images as a Sweeping Visual Diary

body: IN a fancy women's department store in Osaka, Japan, earlier this year, shoppers lined up for one of the latest food fads in the country, jars of pickled herring. title: A Starring Role for the Little Humble Herring

body: St. Vitus, a new metal club, opened in the late spring near the northernmost point of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a block from the Pulaski Bridge. Outside, a black unmarked door. title: MUSIC REVIEW; Metal, Doom and Gloom Included

body: IT'S not quite the same as a sausage fest. Kielbasa is the name of a new gay party held every two weeks in the traditionally Polish neighborhood of Greenpoint, Brooklyn. title: BOîTE; Kielbasa: Greenpoint, Brooklyn

body: WHEN an insurance company declared the merchandise at Leeds Radio ''not pilferable'' last year, it meant that the store's hundreds of thousands of analog electronic parts -- all manufactured before 1968 -- were unlikely to be stolen anytime soon. Richard Matthews, Leeds's wild-haired owner and sole employee, agreed with the assessment. ''Around
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | WILLIAMSBURG; A Haven For Lovers Of the Analog

body: GELLER--Monroe. Died peacefully on November 17, in his 95th year. He was the son of Andrew Geller, a pioneer of women's fashion footwear since the early 1920s, who founded the iconic family business bearing his name, in a factory on Lorimer Street in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. That edifice was a such a fixture in the neighborhood that it was
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GELLER, MONROE

title: THE APPRAISAL; Tower Has Its Own Lawn, But Neighbors Still Look For Their Open Space

body: Once they were so close -- a tight little family making its way through the hard streets of New York. body: WHILE the big-four networks crow about the ratings for ''New Girl'' and ''2 Broke Girls'' and give full-season orders to unexceptional shows like ''Up All Night,'' here's a tip: The smartest, freshest, most moving new sitcom of 2011 finished its first season in September. title: High School, That Hilarious Minefield

body: As dusk fell, a woman, head to toe in black, bounded down the sidewalk, with a leash in one hand and a baby tucked against her chest. By the curb, two men in suits loudly debated the stock market. And at a Mexican bistro, patrons sipped Chardonnay from stemless glasses under graffiti framed as art. Ordinary stuff, maybe, for many New York
title: 26.2 Miles of Change

body: ONE recent Sunday night on the south side of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a crowd of more than 100 men and women in their 20s and early 30s gathered. True to the unspoken dress code of the neighborhood, they were wearing high-waisted skinny jeans, vintage T-shirts and deliberately homely sweaters. One woman in a floral romper, her platinum-blond hair
title: UP CLOSE; A Congregation in Skinny Jeans

body: Jimmy Sturr has been at this awhile. title: MUSIC REVIEW; Giving 'Sweet Home Alabama' a Polish Accent

body: Any bookstore can sell you a book. title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | GREENPOINT; Readers' Hub For Romance. Not the Genre.

body: Opening ONEGIN Plush velour upholstery, crystal chandeliers and a stand of birches in a 122-seat dining room set the stage for Russian food. title: Off the Menu

body: After several failed attempts at encouraging the use of boats to commute across the East River, city officials have an unforeseen problem: too many ferry riders. title: Pleasant Surprise for East River Ferries: Crowds

body: Timothy Haskell, a designer of haunted houses, scares people for a living. title: SUNDAY ROUTINE | TIMOTHY HASKELL; Far From His Usual Haunts

body: Small coffee chains, benefiting from lower retail rents and a seemingly bottomless thirst for high-end coffee even in a weak economy, are seizing the opportunity to expand in New York City. title: SQUARE FEET; Fuel for the City That Never Sleeps

body: A senior official at the New York City agency that helps build affordable housing used his position to conduct a racketeering enterprise, federal prosecutors charged on Thursday, saying he took about $600,000 in bribes and kickbacks from developers who hid the cash in golf ball boxes, coffee cups and overnight envelopes. The official, Wendell B.
title: City Official Accused of Taking Bribes, Left in Boxes and Cups

title: On Facebook, Neighborhoods as They Once Were

title: The Young Gallerists

title: The Atlantic City the Boardwalk Emperor Knew

title: Brooklyn Becomes Book Country Again

body: The new Peter Wilcox is a potato for New York Fashion Week, cloaked in deep purple and lined in gold. title: FOOD STUFF; New Spud on the Block

title: Choosing Cinematheque Over Cineplex

body: It was a steamy summer weeknight, and on a rooftop in Chelsea there was a skyline-lighted party. title: Arts Journal In Cyberspace Finds a Home On the Ground

body: Adam Distenfeld was driving by a construction pit on Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn a few weeks ago and couldn't resist. Mr. Distenfeld, 48, is a sculptor who prefers granite gneiss -- the banded metamorphic rock found beneath swaths of New York City -- and in the Nostrand pit he saw a boulder of it. He had never seen one larger. He needed it. But you
title: CITY ROOM; A Heavy Nuisance Becomes a Sculptor's Niche

body: NEWPORT NEWS, Va. -- Military secrecy was a bit lax during the Civil War, by today's standards, but contractor deadlines were a lot tighter. title: A Brief Dry Spell for the U.S.S. Monitor

body: Millerton, N.Y. title: Williamsburg on the Hudson

title: SPOKES | SEAN PATRICK FARRELL; Bike Vacations Offer Freedom and Frugality

body: MICHAEL ANTHONY admires the butter lettuce he has been buying for the last month so much that he invented a salad for it. title: Want Fresher Produce? Leave Dirt Behind

body: When it comes to produce, there is local, there is hyperlocal, and then there is the Riverpark Farm at Alexandria Center. title: Farm to Table, Literally

body: People straighten up around John Joseph, the singer for the Cro-Mags. He reminds you that the best of his music, New York hardcore, has a history and a set of standards, musical and ethical; he has no time for what people choose to do outside of those standards. He's not hectoring you, exactly, about punk and veganism and the economy and your
title: MUSIC REVIEW; Muscling Through a Murky, Hardcore Night in a Box

body: THE ASTRAL By Kate Christensen 311 pp. Doubleday. $25.95. Lately the realist novel's been getting realistic. title: Eviction Notice

body: A woman in Andrew Plucinski's office is squealing. ''I don't want to look at it!'' She's lying out on a hospital bed, her legs exposed, an arm thrown over her eyes. title: CITY ROOM; Goodbye, Varicose Veins. (Hello, Parasites.)

body: Lorraine Johnson says she remembers the garbage trucks that lined up near her housing project on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, to unload trash at a marine sanitation station on the East River. title: In Fight Against Trash Station, Upper East Side Cites Injustice

title: East River Ferry Service, With 7 Stops, Starts Run

title: Adolfas Mekas, 85, Avant-Garde Filmmaker and Teacher

But in the backyard of 119 Kent Street in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a police officer stood guard near a three-foot mound of dirt, and crime scene tape marked the spot where a work crew had discovered part of a skull and other
title: Skull Found In Backyard Of Old Home In Brooklyn

body: THERE are some who thought, prematurely, that 2010 was New York's summer of the beer garden, what with the World Cup and the opening of a half-dozen outdoor, German-style drinking establishments. But not unlike some genetically altered superweed, these ale-and-oompah joints have continued even this year to crop up everywhere you look. They have
title: SUMMER 2011; Beer Gardens

body: WHEN crowds flock to the Williamsburg Waterfront concert series this summer, most will pass the home of Genya Wolowacz on North Eighth Street, where she has lived since 1957. She will watch them as if eyeing 6,500 barbarian invaders. On a recent evening, Ms. Wolowacz, 67, practically shook with anger as she described what it was like to live near
title: SUMMER 2011; Rocked Hard

body: Little evidence remains of the Faience Manufacturing Company in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. This pottery company failed in the 1890s, and its former headquarters, on Greenpoint Avenue near the waterfront, has served over the years as a pencil factory and an S-and-M club and now contains a sports bar. But in its 1880s heyday, its main designer, Edward
title: ANTIQUES; FOLLOWING THE FAIENCE OF A BROOKLYN DESIGNER

author: E-mail: dwyer@nytimes.com; Twitter: @jimdwyernyt
body: If memory serves, the police captain met me over coffee on a Wednesday night in October 2001, when the world was dizzy with menace. He passed along word of a fresh worry. A young Muslim chemist, who worked in an advanced biochemistry laboratory in Midtown, had vanished on the morning of Sept. 11. Because he had once been a member of a police cadet
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; A Legacy for a Son Whose Character, After 9/11, Was Misjudged

body: At an art opening in Chelsea last week, Erick Magangi stood next to the oil painting that he considered his best work. ''I was trying to do an examination of the real world and the exotic world,'' Mr. Magangi said, gesturing toward the work, an abstract with softly blended horizontal panels of beige and gray. His round face was beaming under a
title: An Outcry in Chelsea Over a 12-Story Shelter

body: KUDZU. Asian carp. Greenhouse gases. Sketch comedy. O.K., maybe short-form humor doesn't belong on a list of ecological scourges. But sometimes it appears to be proliferating as quickly as any of them. Web sites like Funny or Die, College Humor and My Damn Channel post hundreds of short comic videos. On television, ''Saturday Night Live'' chugs
title: WATCHLIST; Second City's Testing Ground in Cyberspace

body: THE folks who run Five Leaves, the cafe and bar in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, known for its ties to the late actor Heath Ledger (he discovered the space while skateboarding on Bedford Avenue), have opened a second pub, Nights and Weekends, around the corner. Large galvanized doors and windows that open onto the sidewalk give the new space (below) the
title: THE MOMENT; Pirate Fare

body: Here are descriptions from Eric Demby, the organizer of Smorgasburg, of vendors that will be at this new open-air food court in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Most are new, but some have been at Brooklyn Flea before. Smorgasburg will be open on Saturdays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., at 27 North Street, between Kent Avenue and the East River (near East River
title: The Vendors: A List of the Smorgasburg Participants

body: COMING Saturday from the folks who unleashed Brooklyn Flea on an unsuspecting universe: Smorgasburg, a conglomeration of about 100 purveyors, including hawkers of handmade food, Greenmarket farmers and cookware vendors, gathering weekly at the East River in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. With pupusas from a Salvadoran immigrant, strawberry-turnip-jam
title: A Food Flea Market Sets Up in Brooklyn

body: Alabama HANGOUT MUSIC FESTIVAL Gulf Shores, May 20-22. Anyone looking to combine two timeless summer pastimes -- beach lounging and festivalgoing -- will be well served by the Hangout Music Festival, which sets up on Alabama's white sand gulf shore for three days each summer. A boon for the less rustic among us (''Shed the mud boots and sleeping
title: SUMMER STAGES; Pop/Jazz

author: J. Courtney Sullivan's second novel, ''Maine,'' will be published next month.
body: Like all good independent bookstores, BookCourt in Brooklyn has a robust section of staff recommendations. There, nestled in with titles by Jennifer Egan, Haruki Murakami and David Foster Wallace, is ''Other People We Married,'' a collection of short stories by Emma Straub. A handwritten note taped to the wall below reads: ''I wrote this book.
title: ESSAY; Don't I Know You From the Dust Jacket?

body: ON a rainy Tuesday last month, in an all-white office space in Brooklyn, a blogger known as swissmiss traded productivity tips with some visiting creative strategists. ''Our own mini-TED,'' she said, half-joking, referring to the high-profile tech conference. Across the room, a prodigious young culture curator, whose Brain Pickings blog has managed
title: Office Party? Let's Tweet It

body: IF devotees of ''The Good Wife'' on CBS scrutinize the elegant, soothing Chicago apartment of Alicia Florrick, they can spot a subtle but symbolic motif: the butterfly. True, subtext is easier to parse when you're touring the show's sets in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. That's when you notice the living room coasters with butterfly designs, the butterfly
title: CULTURAL STUDIES; 'The Good Wife' and Its Women

body: IT'S an unassuming spot for the mecca of East Coast roller derby, this small, narrow shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, beside the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. A handwritten sign on the door reads, ''We are not the bike shop,'' and directs cyclists to nearby King Kog. Many of the shop's visitors come from far beyond the five boroughs. ''Apparently
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | WILLIAMSBURG; These Skates Weren't Made For Strolling

body: ONE recent Saturday night, two Brooklyn roommates were driving home when they passed something odd: an unmarked box truck parked on a desolate block in Greenpoint, spewing strobe-lit, milky fog. ''We just saw these people in costumes and there's smoke pouring out of this truck, and Axel said, 'Stop, drive back,' '' recalled Jon Ernsberger, 28, a
title: All the World's a Stage, Even the Back of a Truck

author: E-mail: habitats@nytimes.com
body: DEBORAH LUTZ, an assistant professor of English with a passion for the Victorians, lived for a decade in a loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. And during those years she did something that the nature-loving Victorians would have understood. In search of closeness to the natural world, she used to spend time in Grand Ferry Park, a local sliver of green
title: HABITATS; Her Decorators? Flotsam & Jetsam

author: Bob Eckstein is a cartoonist for The New Yorker and the author of ''The History of the Snowman.''
body: I played table tennis for the first time in a South Bronx cellar in February 1971, when the sport was called Ping-Pong and my opponent was a gangly adolescent wearing a perm and bell-bottoms. Two months later, a United States Ping-Pong team was invited for a weeklong visit to China, which helped restore relations between the countries and elevated
title: Weathering a Midlife Crisis In the Haunts of Table Tennis

body: THE fitness fanatic in Columbus Circle flaked. So did the performance-artist couple in Greenpoint who said they practiced at-home nudity. Yet Kenya Robinson's odyssey as a serial house guest has been smooth enough so far, and by and large her hosts -- friends, colleagues and total strangers -- have been happy to share their toothpaste with her. Ms.
title: The Serial Sleepover Artist

body: TV ON THE RADIO has made no secret of its catholic taste. Since 2001 this Brooklyn band -- Tunde Adebimpe, Dave Sitek, Kyp Malone, Jaleel Bunton and Gerard Smith -- has made ambitious rock with shades of post-punk, electronica and psychedelic jazz, and lyrics about global politics, love and language. The group made its latest album, ''Nine Types of
title: PLAYLIST | TV ON THE RADIO; Los Angeles, Perhaps, but Brooklyn Is Forever

body: At dozens of struggling schools, New York City education officials have yet to apply for federal money that could help turn them around. Some principals are complaining about reorganizations that have left them without sufficient guidance. Charter school leaders are upset about fights sparked by where the city is placing them. A new teacher
title: A TROUBLED TENURE; In City School System, Hopes That New Leader Can Steer Right Course

title: The Listings

body: 'An Imagined Space' Janet Kurnatowski Gallery 205 Norman Avenue Greenpoint, Brooklyn Through April 23 The artist and writer Emma Bee Bernstein died in 2008 at 23, an age when most people have barely started their life's work. title: ART IN REVIEW; Emma Bee Bernstein

body: Locavores who criticize monocultural farming obviously do not have Patrick Salvati and Dorothy DeMarco in mind. Their Salento Farm in Shelton, Conn., may not be monocultural, but it's close to it. They grow only garlic and eggplant. Their garlic is German hard neck, and they chop it up with garlic scapes, adding olive oil and Parmigiano-Reggiano to
title: FOOD STUFF; All Garlic (and Eggplant) All the Time

title: Corrections

body: Kiefer Sutherland may have left television behind for his latest project, but he brought along the sound effects of ''24'': the hollow pock-pock of the silenced handgun, the crunchy-cereal noise of kneecaps being pulverized. title: WEB REVIEW | 'THE CONFESSION'; In the Confessional Booth With Plenty to Confess

''Irving, baby!'' Mary Ann Lettieri said last weekend as she burst into Manhattan Furrier
title: GREENPOINT JOURNAL; It's the Final Sale for a Longtime Furrier

Nevertheless, Mr. Lazaros says that his work, and that of numerous others, is superheroic. That's why he helped found Superheroes Anonymous, a collective ''dedicated to inspiring the superhero in all people through outreach, education
title: Weekend Miser

title: TRANSACTIONS; Recent Lease

body: Scruffy's DNA was harvested in 2008 from a sample of burnt tissue found in the Brooklyn apartment where teenagers doused him with lighter fluid and set him aflame. title: CITY ROOM; Animals' DNA Is Used to Win Convictions of Abusers

body: MAJOR-LEAGUE athletes have agents who negotiate multimillion-dollar contracts with provisions like private planes and Rolexes. Hollywood actors have agents who scout for their scripts. Now comes Ava Taylor, whom one blogger has called ''the Ari Gold of yoga,'' trying to make a business out of managing the careers of yoga teachers. Yes, yoga
title: STRETCH; Agent Pursues a Cut Of the Yoga Boom

body: THE kombucha guy was doing it wrong, and so was I. By the time Rich Awn, the owner of the one-man tea-and-coffee brewery Mombucha, arrived at the food swap in a TriBeCa apartment building, the table brimmed with inventive homemade goods, including vodka infused with the needles from an organic Christmas tree. Next to each offering was a green
title: NEW YORK STORY; You Cooked What? I'll Trade You Granola!

body: There is a certain species of New York music fan that is ready to skimp on sleep. This person probably has a day job, a career even. But that's not going to stop him (and it is usually, though hardly always, a him) from getting down to live music until 1 in the morning on a Wednesday, if there's a good show to be had. And rocking it again the next
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; The 10-Night Intergalactic Funk Odyssey

body: Cayuga Pure Organics near Ithaca, N.Y., has been one of the leaders of the local grain movement. It is also selling breads made with their grains that are baked by Orwasher's bakery on the Upper East Side. A round whole-grain bread was the first, and Cayuga has added a longer loaf, with a braided pattern on top, called Otis Stout Bread. It is made
title: FOOD STUFF; Otis Stout Bread Makes Its Debut

body: Around 200 parishioners were gathered on a recent Sunday for the 10 a.m. Mass at St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church in Greenpoint, a grand limestone pile a block from the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. ''The bare minimum is for others to do, not for us,'' the pastor, the Rev. James Krische, 52, preached from the pulpit. ''Jesus calls us to leap
title: Artists Find Accommodating Landlord: A Struggling Brooklyn Parish

body: International IRAQI NEIGHBORHOOD Welcomes a Wall's Fall A three-mile-long blast wall built several years ago in the sprawling Shiite neighborhood of Sadr City gradually took on a life of its own, becoming an emblem of people's anger and despair at years of killing and military occupation. But recently, a bulldozer and crane rumbled into the
title: Inside The Times

body: FOR more than a decade, the American real estate market resembled an overstuffed novel, which is to say, it was an engrossing piece of fiction. Mortgage brokers hip deep in profits handed out no-doc mortgages to people with fictional incomes. Wall Street shopped bundles of those loans to investors, no matter how unappetizing the details. And
title: MERS? It May Have Swallowed Your Loan

body: It started randomly, as collaborations often do for young people with high-speed connections, limited budgets and big ideas. Back in the summer of 2009, Jacob Krupnick, an aspiring art photographer in his mid-20s, persuaded a fashion P.R. company to hire him to make a promotional video for a footwear show. He went on Craigslist to recruit 50
title: B-Girl Bouillabaisse

body: OPENINGS Fashion followers may recall lining up at 93 Mercer Street. The storefront is where Rachel Zoe held court during Fashion's Night Out last September for a pop-up Piperlime shop, and where Alexander Wang held sample sales as recently as December. Now the space is home to a joint store stocking Olivier Theyskens for Theory, and Helmut Lang.
title: Scouting Report

body: I DON'T generally make New Year's resolutions. Life is complicated and abundant enough with opportunities for disappointment. I assumed it would be like going to the
title: URBAN ATHLETE; Runner Warms to Williamsburg

body: IN ''The Donut Chef,'' a children's book by Bob Staake, two bakers on one block compete by dreaming up increasingly outlandish pastries: ''Their donuts were such crazy things! Some were square and some were starry. Some looked just like calamari.'' Soon the townspeople can't remember when doughnuts were round and covered with glaze. With a clutch
title: $25 AND UNDER; For the Homer Simpson in All of Us

body: A native of Atlanta, Drake Page was familiar with his family's sweet Southern-style chutneys. He also lived in London, where chutney comes with the cheese in a pub. Now his DP Chutney Collective (a one-man band so far) produces a rotating line of more than a dozen chutneys and ketchups. The aromatic curried peach, top, and the musky sweet tomato
title: FOOD STUFF; Chutney and Ketchup Creations

body: A column that celebrates drinking should pause every once in a while to celebrate not drinking, given that alcohol is a two-edged sword: catalyst for delight and engine of destruction; handled with restraint by some people, abused and best avoided entirely by others. It's a drug, with all the attendant dangers, and it's not the only way to
title: THE TIPSY DIARIES; Cocktails With a Twist: Zing but No Alcohol

body: ON a recent blustery Friday night near McCarren Park in Brooklyn, Nayantara Banerjee, a k a the Williamsburg Seamster, was armored in a poncho sweater, knee-high snow boots from Urban Outfitters and a black-and silver-threaded scarf knotted over her long, jet-black hair. Despite the frigid air, Ms. Banerjee was happy to stretch her limbs. She had
title: Stitch by Stitch And Block by Block

body: THE Brooklyn Cruise Terminal on the Buttermilk Channel has picturesque views even when the Queen Mary 2, which docks there regularly, is at sea. There is verdant Governor's Island across the water and, behind it , the heaving, jagged rise of Manhattan. To the north are the great bridges of the East River. To the west, the Statue of Liberty. And to
title: 36 HOURS; Brooklyn

body: OF all the must-have items for a New York City apartment, stairs generally don't figure very high on the list. Stairs create separation. Stairs take up space. Stairs mean work. There are buyers out there, though, who seek a duplex. They like the separation of public and private rooms. They don't mind losing a little space, and a bit of exercise
title: Take the Stairs

body: With no snow for days, and none in the immediate forecast, the city is moving out of its period of being buried, which began the day after Christmas and never seemed to end. But as the snow melts, and as city officials tally the cost of this record-breaking winter, other price tags are becoming clear -- whether they be financial, emotional, even
title: Crime Down, Bills Up: How Snow Affects the City

''All my life, I dreamed about such a truck,'' he said. ''My wife said, 'O.K., you can buy it.' You
title: AUTO EGO | 1965 FORD ECONOLINE; A Special on His Menu

author: MATT GROSS, the former Frugal Traveler, writes the ''Getting Lost'' series for the Travel section.
body: THE minute I walked into the steakhouse, I knew I was in the wrong place. Or maybe exactly the right place. This was N9ne, at the Palms Casino Resort, a few blocks from the Las Vegas Strip, and it was definitely not my scene. The slick design -- leather in muted colors, steel and aluminum accents, and silly lighting -- was one thing, but I've dealt
title: Lost in Las Vegas

body: For Joe Santos, producing and distributing his own gin was a way to say goodbye to the lock-step march of the corporate world and hello to creativity and originality. He wanted to give the gin a name that communicated that. So he invoked a certain New York City borough, the one currently outpacing the others in self-satisfaction. Brad Estabrooke
title: THE TIPSY DIARIES; Pride of Place In Every Drop

title: The Listings

body: For all their dominance on Staten Island, ferries have long struggled to muscle their way into the city's mass transit mainstream. Experiments in Queens and Brooklyn have been held back by infrequent service, outsize operating costs and low ridership. But the city, unfazed by past failures, is now embarking on a more ambitious plan: a year-round
title: Ferries to Ply East River Far More Regularly Soon

A former Polish butcher shop, it's lined with shelves and counters that feature about 50 cheeses and
title: FOOD STUFF; Try Not to Start Singing '100 Brands of Beer on the Wall'

title: On the Blogs

body: Since receiving her big break (and bagging the first of her two Tony Awards) in ''The Real Thing,'' in 1984, Christine Baranski has carved a career across theater, film and television. title: SUNDAY ROUTINE | CHRISTINE BARANSKI; A Leisurely Day to Learn Her Lines

body: MICHAEL MOSHAN bought his first condo in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in 2003. A few years later he persuaded his girlfriend, Shana Liebman, to move there from the West Village. She was skeptical -- she didn't want to be surrounded by 20-somethings just out of school. But over the years the neighborhood, with its restaurants, bars and galleries, grew on
title: Williamsburg, Toddlertown

author: Jonah Weiner is the pop critic at Slate and a contributing editor at Rolling Stone. This is his first article for the magazine.
body: Brock Enright rents a studio in an old Catholic school in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a former classroom that is hard to navigate without stepping on a drawing or kicking a sculpture, but he makes much of his art beyond his studio's walls -- in bars, fast-food joints, Chinatown shopping plazas, rooftops and other locations throughout Manhattan. One
title: If Your Life Were a Movie

body: ANELLA 222 Franklin Street (Green Street), Greenpoint, Brooklyn; (718) 389-8100, anellabrooklyn.com. title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

body: A listing in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday referred incorrectly to the restaurant Calexico in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. It is the second restaurant opened by the owners of a taco truck of the same name -- not the first, which was Calexico Carne Asada in Carroll Gardens. The listing also misstated the number of years the taco truck has been
title: CORRECTIONS

body: THE Pencil Factory, a new condominium building in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, has many selling points. Its public spaces include a crisply contemporary lobby, a spacious gym and a roof terrace with views across the East River to Manhattan that elicit gasps. The apartments -- 93 mostly one- and two-bedroom units, of 623 to 1,280 square feet -- have sleek
title: POSTING; The 'Elephant' In Each Room

body: A GROWN man leapt to his feet and screamed. Sean Crowley had just announced that Snooki, one of the exquisitely tanned stars of MTV's ''Jersey Shore,'' would not be descending to earth in a transparent ball in Times Square on New Year's Eve. (The event was moved to New Jersey.) This meant that the answer to a question Mr. Crowley had posed was
title: Q. Where To Bend Elbow And Mind?

body: To the Editor: Re ''Wilderness Underfoot'' (news article, Jan. 2): Though there is considerable interest in learning about New York City's 7,400 miles of sewer lines, entering them is not only illegal, but it is also potentially fatal. Sewers pose a series of life-threatening risks: pockets of poisonous gas can build up; temperature changes can
title: LETTER; Advice in New York: Stay Out of the Sewers

title: Off the Menu

His fireworks come from the two tandoors he has installed in the kitchen to produce specialties like wild boar chops, prawns and even tofu. A rolling cart serves street snacks as
title: Off the Menu

body: ANELLA 222 Franklin Street (Green Street), Greenpoint, Brooklyn; (718) 389-8100, anellabrooklyn.com. An intimate little art house of a restaurant, with a narrow bar and dining room decorated in that nice urban variation on farmhouse chic that is common to restaurants in north Brooklyn. The chef is a talented fellow named Joseph Ogrodnek, who offers
title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

body: PAPE--Michael V. passed away on January 5, 2011 at his residence in Scarsdale. He was 95 years old. Mr. Pape was born August 12, 1915 in Greenpoint Brooklyn to Joseph and Rose Pontone Pape. Mr. Pape married his late wife Maria T. pape on September 7, 1940 at Sacred Heart Church in Brooklyn. Mr. Pape was the president of Ace Gear Industries Inc. and
title: Paid Notice: Deaths PAPE, MICHAEL V
